<SOURCE>http://www.dailytrust.com.ng/sunday/index.php/top-stories/21359-monguno-a-no-nonsense-general-takes-on-boko-haram</SOURCE>
<DATE_TIME>2015-07-19T00:00:00</DATE_TIME>
<HEADLINE>
Monguno: A No-Nonsense General Takes on Boko Haram
</HEADLINE>
<TEXT>
.His ancestral home bears scars of the insurgents’ cruelty
.Monguno will surely liberate us - Displaced Person
.He should use the civilian network to gather intelligence – Col Kontagora (rtd)
If the new NSA, retired Major General Babagana Monguno, will have a glance at
available records and see the carnage inflicted on his ancestral town of
Monguno by Boko Haram, he will spare no effort in tackling the menace. In the
last three years, Monguno, a garrison town, thriving farming community and a
crossroads that links many prosperous communities in Borno State was literally
reduced to shreds by persistent attacks by Boko Haram militants.
The onslaughts on Monguno and adjoining communities as well as nearby local
government areas of Kukawa, Marte among others had led to the killings of men,
women and children as well as destruction of properties, farms and other
economic fortunes worth millions of naira. The latest attack on Monguno was on
July 10, when the sect killed 43 persons in Kalwa, Misala and Gwollam
villages. The attacks were launched after similar ones on Maisara 1 and 11 of
the same in the same local government on 30th of June which left 48 people
dead. Witnesses said victims of the latest attacks on the three villages were
either shot or slaughtered.
Before the recent attacks, the town of Monguno had recorded various offensive
that culminated in the complete take over of the town, including the military
barracks on January 25, 2015. It was reported that over 1,000 soldiers at the
barracks retreated after a fierce battle with the Boko Haram. The soldiers
reportedly left behind various weapons lodged at the facility ahead of a
planned operation to recapture Baga, a fishing community along the shores of
the Lake Chad where hundreds of people were massacred early this year. This
was in addition to hundreds of women and children of both military personnel
and the civilians that were held captive by the Boko Haram assailants.
Few days after the attacks, the leader of Boko Haram, Abubakar Shekau appeared
in a video in which he showcased the weapons his fighters seized from Monguno
barracks. Pointing at the cache of arms, Shekau boasted: “These booty (weapons)
you are seeing came from Monguno alone...they are enough for our men to bring
Nigeria to the ground.”
Beside the 7 Division of the Nigerian army with its headquarters at the
Maimalari Barracks in Maiduguri, Monguno has the largest barracks in Borno
State, a development that makes the town strategic to the safety of nearby
towns and villages. After ground operations and aerial reconnaissance, the town
was liberated on February 15, 2015. This paved way for some of the residents,
including many that fled to Niger, Cameroon and Chad to return to the strategic
town. Sadly, some of those who returned ultimately met their death in some of
the latest attacks. Some of those that managed to escape are now living in
Maiduguri together with nearly 1.5 million displaced persons (IDPs).
With this in view, observers believe that the new National Security Adviser to
President Muhammadu Buhari would confront the Boko Haram terrorists headlong.
There are allegations of sabotage within the military hierarchy, lack of
political will, absence of serious support from the international community and
the lack of cooperation from residents of local communities in the fight
against insurgency. For instance on January 28, the Amnesty International
issued a damning release titled: Nigerian authorities were warned of Boko Haram
attacks on Baga and Monguno.
According to Netsanet Belay, Amnesty International’s Africa director, new
evidence showed that the Nigerian military were repeatedly warned of impending
Boko Haram attacks on Baga and Monguno which claimed hundreds of lives, and
failed to take adequate action to protect civilians.
STAKEHOLDERS BELIEVE GENERAL MONGUNO CAN DELIVER
No one expressed confidence and optimism on the capacity of General Monguno in
confronting the Boko Haram monster like Governor Kashim Shettima who said that
the appointment of Monguno to the high position would spell and end to Boko
Haram.
According to him, “Buhari’s choice of retired Major General Babagana Monguno
and Major General Tukur Buratai as National Security Adviser and Chief of Army
Staff respectively, was a classic case of putting square pegs in square holes
because both men have been given the mandate of liberating their State which is
at the centre of Boko Haram activities while they possess ancestral knowledge
of the Borno terrain in addition to being direct victims of insurgency attacks
with their relatives killed, their residences destroyed and their towns
raided.
“President Muhammadu Buhari made a strong statement by his decision to appoint
two highly competent sons of Borno to the offices of the National Security
Adviser and the Chief of Army Staff. I think his strategy was to get people
with ancestral knowledge of the Borno terrain. Major General Tukur Buratai is
even a direct victim of Boko Haram attacks. He lost family members when his
residence was attacked earlier this year in Buratai, a town in Biu Local
Government Area. Monguno was destroyed and once occupied by Boko Haram and that
is where the new NSA, retired Major General Babagana Monguno hails from.
“In fact, a key family member of General Monguno is still being held captive by
Boko Haram insurgents. These two Generals are from Borno, they know exactly
where it pinches and most importantly, they understand the terrain and can
easily connect with communities to get local support.
Similarly, a member of the House of Representatives (Kaga/Magumeri/Gubio
federal constituency in Borno state) Alhaji Mohammed Sanda Ngamdu, said
General Monguno and others would bring an end to Boko Haram terrorism.
“These two top military brasses from Borno state do not only have the military
professionalism and intelligence, but the duo know the terrains, including the
nooks and crannies of this affected sub-region of our country, Nigeria. In
war, you have to know all the aspects of the areas and people, so as to
comprehend and fully understand the modus operandi of insurgents of destruction
of lives and property,” he said.
Kime Yunus, an IDP in Monguno said he had known General Monguno in the last 30
years ago. “He was a rugged fighter even when he was young, he never gave up
fighting, he always won. I see his appointment as a sign of new dawn for us; he
will surely liberate us,” he said.
Speaking on the new NSA, Colonel Isa Kontagora, who was an artillery officer
in the Nigerian Army, said “By his pedigree he is more than qualified. To start
with, the man is knowledgeable. He commanded the Intelligence Defence Agency
and he was in the Doctrine and Command. This is an asset to him. He is calm and
calculative as a person. He is expected to bring these qualities to bear in his
approach to the fight against Boko Haram. The NSA is a victim of Boko Haram.
They overran his community many times. I think he has the advantage of
environment to deal with the insurgency”.
Kontagora, who is a former Military Administrator of Benue and Kano States
during the administration of the late General Sani Abacha, said Monguno has the
Chief of Army Staff to his advantage to succeed in his assignment.
“The Chief of Army Staff also happens to be a victim of Boko Haram. His area,
Buratai, was overran many times by insurgents, even his country home was
touched. The two of them have the knowledge and vast experiences to tackle the
insurgency. From my knowledge of him as an officer in the army, he has the
determination. He should maintain the momentum he has already achieved and
expand where necessary,” he said.
He advised that if the new NSA could use the civilian network he will achieve a
lot. “He can understand better the suffering and agony his people have been
going through in the past five years and as well deal with them. We just hope,
too, that the sponsors of the insurgency will give peace a chance,” Kontagora
reasoned.
A retire General who was a senior to Monguno in NDA said as is the tradition
with students and cadets, his nick name is “Monte” short for Montgomery, the
celebrated British WWII General.
He is noted for the use of the traditional military fatique dress, otherwise
known as Khaki.
He is extremely immaculate in dressing to the extent that he always has three
extra uniforms in his office. The source said when Monguno was the Adjutant of
the Nigerian Defense Academy, NDA Kaduna he change his uniform when he notice
that it has ruffled.
And when he oversees a parade in the morning and the Commandant ordered for
another parade in the afternoon, Monguno would change to a clean and straight
ironed Khaki.
The source confirmed that Monguno doesn’t want to sit when he wore his military
Khaki.
Another junior officer who worked under him said Monguno can be spotted from
afar within his colleagues because of his cleanliness.
He belongs to the Nigerian Army Engineering Corp (NAEME) being an Architect
with a first degree in Symmetric Architecture and PhD in general architecture.
As he grew through the military ranks, he carved a niche for himself for the
quest of excellence and welfare when he was the Commander of Brigade commands a
brigade responsible for the security of the President and the seat of power,
Aso Rock Villa.
He was cherished by soldiers under him for being uncompromising when it came
to the rights and privileges of soldiers, a good characteristic of an officer
and a soldier.
General Monguno was said to have been a member of the “Colour Party” during his
passing out parade from NDA, Kaduna. It is a team of five people selected and
chosen for their unique qualities in military drill, neat in military uniform
and of commanding height. Colour party is always the cream of any parade.
President Muhammadu Buhari said recently that he had to rejig the nation’s
security architecture to end the Boko Haram insurgency. He emphasised that the
Boko Haram insurgency had nothing to do with Islam, saying the military would
support Nigeria in ending the menace.
BACKGROUND OF THE NEW NSA:
Major-General Monguno attended Kings College, Lagos and holds a Bachelor’s
degree in Architecture and a Master’s in International Relations. He was said
to be to longest serving Adjutant of the prestigious military institution and
his alma mater, the Nigerian Defence Academy, Kaduna. Monguno also served as
Commander, Guards Brigade at the end of the reign of the former President
Olusegun Obasanjo and towards the beginning of the administration the President
Umaru Musa Yar’adua. He introduced special allowance for Guards Brigade, which
soldiers called ‘Monguno Allowance.’
He was made the Deputy Commandant, National Defence College, and later the
Chief of Defence Intelligence, CDI, responsible for gathering and compiling
intelligence from all the armed forces, otherwise known as DIA, from July 2009
to September 2011.
He then served as the Chief of Logistics at the Nigerian Defense headquarters
and later as Commandant of the Nigerian Army Training and Doctrine Command
(TRADOC) in Minna.
Prior to his retirement from the Nigerian army he was considered for Chief of
Army Staff position. Monguno voluntarily retired from the Nigerian Army in
September 2013 after turning 56, the age ceiling for Majors General in the
Nigerian army.
Major-General Monguno is the nephew of elder statesman former politician,
Minister of Petroleum, Internal Affairs, Mines and Power, OPEC Chairman and
philanthropist, Dr Shettima Ali Monguno. He is an erudite polyglot, as he
speaks the three main Nigeria’s languages (Hausa, Yoruba and Igbo) fluently
He was appointed the National Security Adviser on July 13, 2015 by President
Muhammadu Buhari.
Monguno is still being held captive by Boko Haram insurgents. These two
Generals are from Borno, they know exactly where it pinches and most
importantly, they understand the terrain and can easily connect with
communities to get local support.
Similarly, a member of the House of Representatives (Kaga/Magumeri/Gubio
federal constituency in Borno state) Alhaji Mohammed Sanda Ngamdu, said

They overran his community many times. I think he has the advantage of
environment to deal with the insurgency”.
